MainHeading.Title: Health Services Eligibility: Motion.

Speaker.P: I move:

That Dáil Éireann, noting the serious and growing anomaly in the income eligibility limits of non-manual workers for health services and maternity care under the Health Acts relative to manual workers, and in particular noting that with rising income levels many thousands of non-manual workers are now excluded from free hospital care, calls on the Government to abolish all income limits forthwith.

We tabled this motion because of growing dissatisfaction and concern among ordinary people because they are being increasingly denied their rights to free hospitalisation. There have been many anomalies created by the definition of manual and non-manual workers and consequently a series of problems have been created. I have not been able to get clarification on this from the Minister, who has said it rightly rests with the health boards. Because of this lack of clarification we find ourselves in serious trouble. For instance, a bus driver is a manual worker but a bus conductor is not; a butcher is a manual worker but a shop assistant is not; an engine driver is a manual worker but a ticket collector may not be so described.

MainHeading.P: This kind of thing was all right in the early fifties when social welfare legislation to deal with it was being drafted, but it has no relevance to today's conditions. In those days, manual workers were very lowly paid and there was no income limit for them. Nowadays we find a manual worker having eligibility although he is earning £250 a week but a non-manual worker with £4,000 a year is not eligible because of this distinction. It is because of the variety and number of the anomalies that we on these benches did not agree with the Fine Gael motion. We suggest there is only one answer, and that is total abolition of the present system and implementation of a free hospital scheme for all.

If our priorities were right and we had a choice of a free family doctor service or free hospitalisation, we would opt for the former for the entire community. We do not have that option and therefore there are thousands of people who find themselves in serious difficulties and will continue to be in such difficulties untill the matter has been clarified by the Minister. Without such clarification, 85,000 people will find themselves in difficulties this year in regard to eligibility for free hospital services. It appears to be the Minister's intention to ensure that those who had an income of £3,000 in 1976 will continue to be eligible for free hospitalisation up to 1979. I will quote a statement by the Minister on this matter from column 313 of Volume 305 of the Official Report. In reply to a question on 11 April last the Minister said in the Dáil:

All insured workers who were eligible because their earnings came within the £3,000 limit when it was first introduced in July 1976 are still eligible, and will retain this eligibility at least until the beginning of 1979, even though their incomes may since have exceeded this limit.

I should like the officers of health boards to pay attention to that declaration by the Minister, which was made without equivocation. Even though their incomes since may have exceeded £3,000 per annum they will remain eligible, according to the Minister, until 1979. That statement by the Minister eliminates doubts on this matter.

Indeed the Minister will create more problems for himself if he begins to try to remedy the existing anomalies. That is not the way to do it. His predecessor announced in October 1973 that he would be having discussions with the medical profession on this. These discussions took place over a period of many months and I had regular reports on them. The report given to the medical profession was that shadow boxing was going on and that there were no actual negotiations going on in the Department. Perhaps that is a one-sided view but that is the information given to me.

I sounded out the medical profession on the issue and I have no doubt that they would be prepared and more than happy to operate a completely free hospitalisation scheme. They did remark that the Minister said the cost would be £1.8 million and that perhaps the decimal point was in the wrong place and it should be £18 million. Be that as it may, they were prepared to operate this scheme but they would not operate it under the present method of payment to consultants which was introduced by the Health Act, 1953 and which paid consultants under a pool payments scheme.

It was an iniquitous system and operated as follows: a consultant was paid for every day the patient was in hospital. First, this was wrong in principle because it encouraged consultants to keep patients in hospital. Secondly, they were paid a miserable fee. For instance, a surgeon might perform a major heart operation lasting six or eight hours and in return he would get as much as £6. This is a very complicated and complex system. As I said, this was an iniquitous scheme in every respect because it encouraged consultants to keep patients in hospital.

For years, consultants have been trying to rid themselves of this terrible system. They were prepared to operate the scheme at the beginning because they said they had a high proportion of private patients who were outside the insurance scheme who would be charged more. If the Minister were to bring in a total, free hospitalisation scheme they felt they could not and would not operate it under the pool payments scheme. They said the Minister had miscalculated his estimate of what it would cost and that is why they said the decimal point was in the wrong place.

A while ago the Minister said that a free hospitalisation scheme would cost £17 million. I would like to show him that it will not; I would like to talk about what it will cost. When we talk about a free hospitalisation scheme we are talking about 15 per cent of the population because 85 per cent of the public have entitlement to free hospitalisation. Of that 15 per cent we may safely say there will be 5 to 7 per cent who will not avail of the free hospitalisation scheme because they will opt for private care, as happened in Britain. We can talk now in terms of the 10 per cent.

If we pay the consultants the same rates paid by the VHI for in-patient services for private patients in 1976, this would work out at £9.25 million for ordinary hospitalisation care. If we talk about an average of six days maternity—the maximum—we are talking in terms of £550,000. If we take £70 per doctor for delivery of babies, we are talking in terms of another £470,000. At 1976 prices this would work out at £10.27 million. If we bring that up to today's figures the cost of a free hospitalisation scheme would be £12.6 million. I do not think I have been trimming or cutting the figures because I have given the returns of the Voluntary Health Insurance Board for the people who are ineligible under the present system for free hospitalisation. At today's figures, allowing for 12 per cent and 8.5 per cent, I calculate it would cost £12.6 million. That is a far cry from the Minister's figure of £17 million.

How will we get £12.5 million? Let us look at what we get from car tax. We should talk about what the car tax and the wealth tax cost the State. The cost vis-à-vis the other benefits issued would not be enormous and in one fell swoop the Minister could solve the whole problem. Admittedly he has to negotiate with the profession and, like any trade union, they want to negotiate with him. I think there would be no problem there. All he has to do is talk to them.
I hope the Minister's reply is not being torn up. I thought I had converted him and that there was no need to speak.

Speaker.P: This is a note dealing with the technicalities of the discussion.
I have explained them so well he does not need them. That is very interesting.
The Deputy is doing very well at short notice.

First, the cost would not be phenomenal. He could negotiate a settlement of fee per item of service or schedule of fees, a sessional fee and perhaps a salary plus off duty hours for surgeons and others working in health board areas. The question of negotiating with the profession would not be a major problem. The Minister will agree, and I do not think I am flattering him too much when I say that as he has the confidence of the profession a problem would not arise.

How is he going to get the money? We could talk in terms of what he is aiming to introduce. Will it be pay-related social welfare and health contributions? I firmly believe that if all workers, farmers, self-employed, directors and others, were to pay social welfare contributions under a pay-related scheme, 1 per cent or even 2 per cent would bring in the necessary money. We could do this and eliminate the many anomalies which exist and so solve the problem.

An argument is being put forward that this would put a tremendous burden on our hospitals and that they would be unable to cope. There is no reason why the subvention to the private hospitals could not be increased to enable them to operate within the system. The Minister knows that if he were to increase the subvention he would get the full cooperation of the private hospitals who could provide the extra beds that would be required were such a tremendous demand to be made on the national hospitalisation scheme. We need not fear that the dangers that have been suggested would arise were a free hospitalisation scheme to be introduced. The arguments in relation to beds, the profession and the problems that would arise can be discounted to a large extent.

MainHeading.P: There would be a problem in collecting money from the farming community. On checking up today I discovered that the farming community owe the Department about £500,000 in health contributions. That is not fair to the PAYE workers who must pay weekly contributions compulsorily while the farmers get away with it because it is so difficult to collect the £24 a year. To owe the State £500,000 is serious and significant and some effort should be made to recover the money. If it were compulsory for everyone to have an insurance stamp this would solve the problem of the self-employed, the directors, the farmers and so on. This is the case in Britain and there is no reason why it could not be introduced here.

We are one of the few countries in the EEC that do not provide free hospitalisation. Twelve million pounds would provide free hospitalisation. It cost the State £28 million to abolish car tax and six times what I have suggested it would cost to abolish the eligibility limit, to remove the rates, and £8 million to abolish the wealth tax. We must put things into proper perspective when we wish to benefit the population. I am inundated with complaints by people who are just barely outside the eligibility limit who have to pay the full hospitalisation charges. The Minister may say that there is voluntary health insurance for those who are ineligible but the voluntary health insurance does not provide free maternity service. The full cost of maternity services must be borne by people who are just outside the eligibility limit. It costs up to £300 for delivery and £20 odd a day for a bed in the Coombe Hospital and from £70 to £150 for the services of an obstetrician. The answer to the problem is not for people who are outside the limit to join the VHI: the only answer is a proper free hospitalisation scheme.

I found a lot of faults in the motion which Fine Gael had put down. If we were to increase the eligibility on the basis of income we would again create further anomalies. In relation to the £60 valuation, on checking with the Department I found that that was equivalent to £5,400 a year for a PAYE worker. That is a terrible discrepancy and disparity. The farmer can have £5,400 a year but the manual worker can only have £3,000. This will continue to be wrong as long as we have this basis for deciding eligibility for free hospitalisation.

The Minister stated that he will definitely not bring in free hospitalisation and that he has the report of the working party established to investigate how pay-related contributions work. The motion as proposed by the Fine Gael Party would have been debated in a vacuum unless the Minister came forward with the report. I hope that in this debate the Minister will provide us with a rough outline of the report. Is it the Minister's intention to introduce another ceiling of, say, £5,000 or £6,000 instead of the £3,000? Will there be a separate health and social welfare contribution and if so will the Minister keep the contribution to 6 per cent of total expenditure, or is it the intention to increase this dramatically? How can the Minister bring in another ceiling of, say, £5,000 without at the same time creating tremendous difficulties for those who would be just outside the limit? Will the Minister make a ceiling for manual workers and for non-manual workers? If the Minister makes a ceiling of £5,000 or £6,000 for non-manual workers he will create a serious problem because in effect he will be denying the right of manual workers to free hospitalisation irrespective of their income. In creating a ceiling for one and all the Minister would create perhaps the most serious problem he could encounter as Minister for Health. There would be a revolt among the manual workers who would be denied their rights under the Social Welfare Act. My arguments illustrate that the answer is not to bring in a new ceiling, not to extend the limit of eligibility, but once and for all to say: “It is free hospitalisation; I am in favour of it and I am going to have a pay-related contribution scheme”.

I should like to see the Department get its own money so that it has full control over this scheme and not have the finance coming from the Department of Finance. I believe that the State, operating a proper pay-related scheme, can provide the necessary finance to provide a free hospitalisation scheme. I have costed it, based on VHI figures; it is not impossible. I suggest the Minister would have no difficulty in bringing about a speedy solution to negotiations with the Department of Health were he to operate the VHI system of payment to the doctors. Once and for all, he would have the whole problem solved. It is £12.6 million at today's prices, not an enormous amount and, having regard to the fact that the pay-related contributions would cover it, he could get agreement with the profession and would not be bringing on his head the wrath of the manual workers who will be deprived of eligibility as a number of them will be under a new ceiling scheme. The only answer is a free hospitalisation scheme. Also, he would not face the problem that has been mentioned, that the hospitals would not be able to cope with admissions, if he were to bring in the private hospitals and increase subventions to them.
The solution is not extending the limit of eligibility; it is not the text of the Minister's amendment which notes:

...that it is the Government's intention to review the income limits and criteria of eligibility for the purposes of limited eligibility for health services in conjunction with the introduction of a pay-related health and social insurance contribution scheme in April 1979.

From that, it would seem that the Minister proposes a new ceiling denying perhaps thousands of manual workers their rights established over many years. I base my idea of the Minister's intention on his amendment to our motion and I would say that he is creating serious problems for his Department and the Government. I ask him to consider the matter seriously and perhaps even say that he is prepared to discuss and consider the problem of ending once and for all this terrible inequity.

I should like the Minister—and it is important for him to do it now—and his Department to issue a directive to the health boards who are not aware of the Minister's statement in the House, that all those whose income came within the limit of £3,000 in 1976 are eligible for free hospitalisation up to at least 1979. I know the Minister feels that way inclined and has stated this but I want him to say it to the health board officials who are not carrying out the Minister's wishes in this regard. If he did this I feel sure that in the meantime, while he is considering my proposals for free hospitalisation, he might relieve the anxiety of so many people who find themselves at present ineligible.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Haughey) Minister for Health (Mr. Haughey)
Speaker.P: I move the following amendment:
To delete all words after “Dáil Éireann” and substitute the following:

“notes that it is the Government's intention to review the income limits and criteria of eligibility for the purposes of limited eligibility for health services in conjunction with the introduction of a pay-related health and social insurance contribution scheme in April 1979”.

At the outset—and I am sure the Chair will agree with me on this— may I say that I would like to congratulate Deputy O'Connell on proposing this motion on this complicated matter at such short notice and on making such a knowledgeable contribution. That is not to say that I agree with everything he says but I think everybody in the House would understand that it shows that he has a very thorough and competent knowledge of our health services when he is able at such short notice to speak with such authority on a complex matter of this kind.

MainHeading.P: I think there is general agreement on the need to review the figure of £3,000 which governs eligibility for hospital and maternity services at present. I do not agree, however, that the figure needs to be changed immediately, particularly when the whole question of eligibility for these services will have to be looked at afresh in the context of the introduction of the new pay-related contributions scheme next April. I hope to satisfy the House that it is wiser to wait on that review rather than to complicate an already very intricate system of eligibility by changing the figure of £3,000 at this stage. I am reinforced in my view by the fact to which Deputy O'Connell has adverted namely, that there is no insured worker who was eligible because his earnings came within the limit in July 1976, when the change was made, who will go out of benefit of eligibility before the beginning of 1979 at the earliest. I think Deputy O'Connell understands how that works but perhaps for the benefit of other Deputies I shall run over it.

When the limit was raised to £3,000 in July 1976 the following situation obtained: any worker who went over the figure of £3,000 subsequently retained eligibility until the end of the contribution year and two full years after that. The statement which I have made and to which Deputy O'Connell adverted and which he has asked me to confirm and which I now confirm is true, namely, that nobody will go out of eligibility for limited eligibility who was eligible because he was within the limit in July 1976 until the end of 1979 at the earliest.

Speaker.P: Sorry, Minister— 1978?

Yes, 1978, the beginning of 1979 or the end of 1978 at the earliest. That gives us time to go into this situation and to take fairly important crucial decisions which will affect the future of our health services for a considerable time to come. And it is as well that we should have that time. I am prepared to discuss the situation with Deputy O'Connell or with Deputy Boland, the Fine Gael spokesman on Health, at any time between now and the end of this year, if they wish to put any particular points of view before me. I am quite certain that I shall be receiving many submissions, and contributions and much advice from interested bodies between now and then.

MainHeading.P: Let me first refer to the past history of this income limit for the record. It was first fixed at £600 in 1953, was adjusted to £800 in 1958, to £1,200 in 1966 and to £1,600 in 1971. These limits applied both to insured workers and self-employed persons and for both categories the £1,600 limit remained in effect until April 1974. Then, the limit for insured workers was raised to £2,250 and remained at that level until July 1976. The limit for self-employed persons remained, however, at £1,600 from 1971 until July 1976. The present limit of £3,000 a year was then fixed for both the insured workers and the self-employed.

I am not giving that history of this income limit figure because I think that the way things were decided in the past should necessarily determine how we are going to decide them in the future. I mention that to bring out the point that it has always been accepted that there were sound practical reasons for not making changes in the limit too frequently. Indeed, during the years up to 1976 when inflation was at a much greater rate than at present there was probably a greater case for more frequent changes in the income limits than there is at present.

One of the criticisms levelled at the present system of limited eligibility for health services is that it is too complex and not easily understood. That is a criticism we must all recognise. The reason for it is that changes had to be made in the system from time to time to meet the needs of changing circumstances. The result is that there is a widespread misunderstanding about how the system works and what cover it provides. In fact, there was a question on the Order Paper recently, put down by a Deputy with some experience, and the nature of it indicated that he did not understand fully how the system worked. It might be helpful if I availed of this opportunity to describe in some detail how limited eligibility operates and, in doing so, to refer in particular to the aspects of it which have been criticised.

The services which are made available to persons with limited eligibility are in three main categories. Firstly, there is free hospital service for both in-patients and out-patients. This includes the major diagnostic procedures such as X-rays and laboratory tests. Secondly, there is free maternity and infant welfare services. This covers general practitioner services as well as hospital and specialist services. It is important to note that the free maternity and infant welfare services which are included cover general practitioner services. The third is that there is a refund of part of the cost of prescribed medicines. In effect, this limits the monthly outlay on medicines to £6.50. Persons who have limited eligibility may also be put in three broad categories; (1) insured workers, subject to a remuneration limit of £3,000 per annum in the case of non-manual workers; (2) self-employed and others subject to an income limit of £3,000 per annum and (3) farmers with a valuation of £60 or less, as mentioned by Deputy O'Connell.

The great majority of persons with limited eligibility are in the first category, insured workers and their families. In this category the income limit applies to non-manual workers but not to manual workers. This is emerging as the major anomaly in the system and one which is subject to the severest criticism. The preferential treatment given to manual workers vis-à-vis non-manual colleagues is not of recent origin. It dates back to the time when the status of the manual worker was such that special provision had to be made for him in the social welfare code. With the improvements which have taken place in the working conditions and status of manual workers the need to make this distinction has largely disappeared. In fact, the distinction between manual and non-manual workers has been eliminated for purposes of social insurance.

The operation of the income limit for non-manual workers is not always fully understood. The present limit is £3,000 per annum. Any person whose remuneration is within this limit is eligible but if his remuneration goes over the limit he does not immediately lose eligibility. In fact, he retains eligibility for the balance of the social welfare contribution year in which the remuneration limit is exceeded and for two further such years. This provision can therefore result in prolonging entitlement for as much as three years after the limit has been exceeded. A worker who was within the £3,000 limit on or after 1 July 1976, when it first came into operation, is still eligible no matter what income he has now. At worst his eligibility will expire at the beginning of 1979. It is not therefore correct to infer that rising income levels are excluding thousands of non-manual workers from eligibility. There are many workers whose pay was within the £3,000 limit when it was first introduced in July 1976 but which has since exceeded that limit. In some cases the amount by which the limit has been exceeded is quite considerable. These workers have not lost eligibility, nor is there any question of their losing it this year. If there is any problem in this regard in any individual case Deputies should notify me immediately.

As I have said, I appreciate that a limit of £3,000, as such, is now out of date. An advantage of the provisions which I have just described however is that in times of rapid movements in earnings it is not immediately necessary to make compensatory changes in eligibility limits. Even though the limit may have fallen behind the movements in earnings, this does not have any immediate effect on eligibility. The operation of the carryover entitlement provisions gives a period of grace in which a review of the eligibility criteria can be carried out and the limit can be revised. As I said, earlier, that is what we hope to do now.

I know that there can be individual cases which can be excluded harshly from eligibility pending a periodical review of the limit, but there is a “hardship” provision which enables eligibility for specific services to be extended to otherwise ineligible persons including those who have exhausted the standard requirements. This provision safeguards the position of persons who, though they are ineligible by reference to the standard criteria, may yet be unable to meet the cost of a necessary service. It has an essential complementary role to the normal rules of eligibility. It adds flexibility to the system by providing that persons whose income may be just outside the limit are not necessarily debarred from availing of a service which they require. Deputies know about this but it is important that we should not think that just because we know about it that everybody knows. There is that important provision overriding everything else, that anybody who needs a particular service and who can clearly show that he cannot avail of that service without hardship can be granted the service free of charge or on a special condition by the CEO.

The question of charging the £60 valuation limit for farmers was referred to in the Fine Gael motion which has fallen by the wayside, but I should like to deal with it now that we are discussing this whole situation. One advantage of this criterion of eligibility is that the selected valuation figure is not disturbed by inflation. A change in money values or an increase in farm incomes does not affect farm valuation. It does not therefore affect the eligibility of farmers. The reasons why the £3,000 limit is going out of date and needs to be reviewed do not apply to valuation and there is not the same case for changing this criterion. Indeed, if one applies a realistic multiplier to valuation to assess its equivalent in present-day farmers' incomes I am sure that £60 would equate to much more than £3,000 per year. That is a point made by Deputy O'Connell.

Deputy O'Connell proposes that all income limits be abolished, and that has certain attractions. In effect, that would involve the extension of free hospital services to the entire community. To do this would inevitably add further to the cost of the health services. If, however, there is an overwhelming need for this extension of services then I think we would have to face up to the difficulty which it would create. We must question, however, whether such a need does in fact exist. Our present objective is to ensure that everybody who needs hospital services is able to obtain such services without incurring financial hardship. If this objective is being achieved equitably and uniformly throughout the country then the case for diverting our resources for a free-for-all hospital service rather than towards other priority areas in the health services is open to question.

I suspect that Deputy O'Connell has mixed feelings about this matter. He is on record as saying that he would prefer to see moneys devoted to the general medical service rather than to a free hospitalisation scheme if that was the necessary priority. To some extent he agrees with that again this evening. That is a very rational view to take, particularly in view of the fact that I know that Deputy O'Connell, and most Deputies, subscribe to the policy objectives which I have and former Ministers have had of trying to keep people out of hospitals rather than in them and to get away from this hospital-obsessed concept of Irish medicine. We want to try to devote increasing resources to community facilities and community medicine, to health centres and clinics in the community. We want more medicine and health services brought out to the people in the community, more people kept in their community. That opens up a large field which I do not intend to debate now.

I should like to refer to hospital charges. It may be helpful if I describe in some detail the context in which these charges are made. There is no charge for hospital services provided in public ward accommodation for persons with full eligibility or with limited eligibility for health services. Charges are payable only by persons who are not eligible for health services and by eligible persons who decide to make private arrangements with a consultant of their own choice for treatment in private or semi-private accommodation.

It has been the practice to adjust these charges from time to time in the light of increases in hospital costs and the disparity between the charges levied and the actual cost of the services provided. It is estimated that the cost of general hospital services will rise to £180 million for 1978 from a figure of about £152 million for 1977. This represents an increase of just over 18 per cent. The charges payable have always been very substantially less than the actual cost of services, and although the charges have been increased by 20 per cent, which is marginally greater than the estimated increase in the cost of services, the revised charges will in the case of the major hospitals represent, on average, only about 50 per cent of the actual cost of services for ineligible persons. For example, the revised charge for private accommodation in a voluntary teaching hospital is about £20 a day. The actual cost will be as high as £40 a day. In the case of eligible persons the charge for private accommodation will represent, on average, only about 20 per cent of the actual cost in the larger hospitals. I think, therefore, it will be generally accepted that the increases in the rates of charge are not unreasonable.

Most persons who are liable for hospital charges are insured with the Voluntary Health Insurance Board. I should mention in this regard that the board are currently arranging to allow members who may be underinsured on the basis of the revised charges to increase their cover with effect from 1 May and in advance of ordinary renewal dates. About 640,000 persons are at present covered under the Voluntary Health Insurance Scheme— and I think Deputies will agree that is a very impressive figure; it reflects the great success of the Voluntary Health Insurance Scheme—of whom about 190,000 have statutory entitlement to services but take out the insurance cover needed to meet the charges payable in respect of private or semi-private accommodation. That is another very interesting figure. Of that 640,000, 190,000 who would have eligibility nevertheless take out cover for private or semi-private accommodation.

I need hardly say that if a person is not eligible for free hospital services, or if, being eligible, he or she would choose private or semi-private care in the event of needing to go to hospital, it would be prudent for him or her to take out insurance with the Voluntary Health Insurance Board and to be guided by the board on the extent of the cover needed. It is apparent from the numbers covered by the scheme that it is a very attractive proposition. The cost of insurance is not likely to cause hardship. For example, in the case of a married man with two children who decides to take out cover for semi-private accommodation based on the latest minimum number of maintenance units recommended by the Voluntary Health Insurance Board, the gross annual cost of insurance against hospital maintenance charges will now be about £104 a year. Of course, these insurance premiums are eligible for income tax relief.

This means that in the case of a person whose maximum rate of income tax is 35p in the £ the income tax relief on a premium of £104 a year will be just over £36 a year. Thus the net cost of insurance in this case will be of the order of £68 a year. The important point in this context, however, is that for such a man the cost of “topping-up” voluntary health insurance cover to meet the increase in charges this year will be only £10.20 gross. For a single person, the cost would be only £3.48. In each case, the increased amount would, of course, be tax-deductible. I recognise in saying all that, that the big gap is cover for maternity, I suppose, the theory being that the family man is expected to anticipate maternity.

He is expected, I suppose, to make provision for this not unexpected event. If for any reason an ineligible person fails to insure against illness with the Voluntary Health Insurance Board and is faced with a bill for hospital costs which he finds difficulty in meeting he can apply for assistance to the health board. It is important again that I should emphasise this. As I have already explained, the health board has power to provide a service for an ineligible person who is considered by the chief executive officer of the board to be unable, without undue hardship, to provide the service from his own resources. Even if there is no eligibility, no voluntary health insurance, the resources of the system are still not exhausted and the CEO can step in and provide the benefit in cases of hardship.

It is, I think, important to emphasise, because of the misunderstanding that persists about the operation of limited eligibility, that the criteria of eligibility will be reviewed and changed, as necessary, before any large-scale loss of eligibility arises.

As I said, the existing system gives us this carry over, this time, in which to come to decisions between now and the end of the year. I accept that the rules of eligibility are not satisfactory. Deputy O'Connell asked about the difference between manual and non-manual workers. There is a guide which CEOs use for their own purposes under which they endeavour to distinguish between professions or vocations which are manual and non-manual. Having said that, I admit it is very anomalous to find when two men are working in a pub, one is a foreman and he is ineligible, and the other is a barman and he is eligible and so on. I could give many other examples of the same sort. I am aware that there are a number of anomalies and that an income limit of £3,000 has been affected by inflation. The rules are such however that the eligibility of workers whose income came within the limit when it was first introduced is not now at risk. Their eligibility is guaranteed at least until the beginning of 1979. In the meantime the income limit and criteria of eligibility will be the subject of very careful examination and review. As I have already indicated I have the report of the working party.

MainHeading.P: In doing this review, the objective of ensuring that nobody will be denied necessary hospital treatment and other health services because of inability to pay must be the principal aim. The need to have the system applied equitable and uniformly to all sections of the community is also a high priority. In addition, within the constraints imposed by these requirements it is important that the criteria of eligibility are such that they are easily understood and that nobody is left in any doubt about what services he is entitled to. These are all worth-while objectives and, while it is clear that they will not easily be achieved, I do not think many people will dispute the desirability of doing so and the desirability of concentrating our efforts on making this major change in 1979, so as to remove all anomalies from the system and provide a better basis for the future planning of it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: May I first of all thank you, a Leas-Cheann Comhairle, for the manner in which you allowed the Labour Party motion to be taken at such short notice. I want to apologise for the inability of the Fine Gael spokesman on health, who is indisposed, to deal with the Fine Gael motion. I also want to thank the Minister for accepting this motion at short notice. I appreciate the Minister's co-operation in this matter.

I will confine my remarks to the question of the £3,000 per annum limited eligibility for the services from the various health boards in respect of non-manual workers and the £60 valuation in respect of farmers. Besically on this motion I am interested in non-manual workers.

MainHeading.P: Despite what the Minister had to say in relation to the position since July 1976, that those who were eligible as at July 1976 would remain eligible up to the beginning of 1979, I suggest that his sweeping statement, while seemingly correct, contains certain anomalies which I should like to point out to him. For instance, what about people who take up non-manual employment and earn in excess of £3,000? They immediately become ineligible for services under the various health boards. That is one of the anomalies that arises from the Minister's tardiness in changing the income limit. As I understand it, the statement of July 1976 is only valid under national wage agreements. In other words, those who were eligible under the £3,000 threshold will continue to be eligible only under national pay agreement increases. They will not be eligible if their salary increases are by way of increments, overtime payments, productivity payments or payments for anomaly claims under wage agreements.

While the Minister's statement seems to be all-embracing, it must be obvious that that is not so, particularly in respect of those who take up non-manual employment where the income of £3,000 is not high. It is not high now because of the savage rate of inflation which we experienced in the past three years. An income of £3,000 is not high and is one which is frequently paid to non-manual workers with any kind of ability. There is need for an immediate raising of the threshold. I am disappointed that the Minister has not seen fit to raise the threshold though he freely admits that the £3,000 limit is unsatisfactory. I appreciate that he is introducing a pay-related health contribution scheme in April next year. We can only look forward to that scheme to a certain extent. I wonder what the workers' contribution will be to that new scheme. When one considers the increases in the insurance scheme in this year's budget one would be hesitant to welcome the new scheme until one sees the fine print. A better way would have been immediately to change the £3,000 limit on non-manual workers.

The Minister mentioned the position of workers above eligibility limits, whether full or limited eligibility limits, who contract a chronic disease or one which requires expensive medicine on a continuous basis. It is my experience that the health board officers are sympathetic and helpful in these cases. I would ask the Minister to make more public the complete list of diseases which qualify for special financial assistance. Many people are not aware of their rights under the Health Act in respect of a number of serious illnesses.

I should like to compliment the directors of community care, the superintendent assistance officers and assistance officers, who do excellent work in dealing with what can only be described as delicate matters. In some places the assistance officers come in for a fair bit of criticism from those who have been disappointed. The assistance officers perform a valuable service for the community and they disburse the money that is available to them very fairly. They also have responsibility for issuing medical cards.

In relation to the VHI scheme, the mover of the motion, Deputy O'Connell, said that it would cost £12.6 million to transfer it to central funds. This is a difficult policy area. There is not a great demand for a full free health service.

Speaker.P: A free hospital service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: There is a feeling abroad that one should provide for one's illnesses. At the same time, I want to make it clear that a priority in my party's health programme is that the hospital care provided for those who benefit under the Health Act should be at least equal to the care that is available to private patients. It is also important that our public schools be of the same standard as our private schools. That comparison must always be there. Without it there would be a loss of confidence in our democratic institutions. It is important that our public hospital services be of a high standard. There should be a choice in relation to the type of service a patient wishes to use and the precautions he wishes to take for his own health and the health of his family. The society in which we live appreciates the availability of alternatives and we should not be too dogmatic about this aspect of health policy.

MainHeading.P: With regard to his statement, the Minister is burying his head in the sand. His proposals in respect of next April are not going to solve this anomaly. He has given no indication whatsoever of the contents of his proposed scheme, and because of that I have become suspicious of his intentions in this matter. I am sorry that he spoke before me because I would like him to answer my case in relation to those within the working sphere who earn over £3,000 and who will now not be eligible for hospital and health care. It is an area which he and his predecessor in government should have tackled and so it is not necessarily a political argument because the present Minister can always point the finger at that. Nevertheless, I am convinced that an anomaly exists in this area, and the Minister should have seen fit to take the bull by the horns and amend the threshold.

Speaker.P: I support the Minister's amendment. An important point, which has been stressed on a previous occasion by the Minister and which Deputy O'Connell mentioned, is that anybody who was eligible for the limited eligibility service in July 1976 will maintain that eligibility up to the end of December of this year. Those who are getting an increase in their income during the year and find themselves going above the £3,000 are mainly the people who are concerned about their ability to pay for the hospital service and the other services under limited eligibility. It is important to point out for people entitled to limited eligibility what services they are entitled to. They are entitled to free hospital service in a public ward. It is important to stress that this is in a public ward, because one of the problems we meet as members of health boards is that occasionally when a person goes into private accommodation he may feel when he comes out of hospital that he is unable to meet the cost and then he will try to get the health board to meet it. The health boards generally are not in a position to do this because the applicant has opted for private accommodation. Other services on limited eligibility are the free maternity service, the free general practitioner service and the free infant care service for the first six weeks after the baby is born. There is also a subsidy on drugs for those who spend more than £6.50 a month on their drug bill. Patients suffering from what are known as long-term illnesses have access to free drugs in any case.

MainHeading.P: Deputy O'Connell made an interesting point when he was talking about the costing of a free comprehensive hospital service. He mentioned the cost of the removal of the car tax, and I wondered if he was suggesting that the car tax might be maintained in order to give the 15 per cent——

Speaker.P: No, I was putting it in proper perspective.
I would not like to think that Deputy O'Connell was suggesting that we rob the poor to treat the rich.
The 15 per cent are the doctors, teachers and so on who are outside the limit. It is not the rich.
The 15 per cent would be classified as the better off section.
No, unfortunately.

They are certainly better off than the people who have the car tax relief. The hospital out-patients departments in my area have done an excellent job but they are taxed to the limit to cater for those who are already eligible for their services. If there was any sudden change at present they would not be able to cope with the increased numbers who would be eligible for the service.

MainHeading.P: In relation to health contributions, a Bill was going through to increase the health contribution this year. I mention again the question that Dr. O'Connell brought up of farmers not paying their contributions. In some of the health board areas at the moment there are threats of legal action against those who will not pay their contributions. There is a certain difficulty in the method by which health contributions are collected because there are three different avenues through which this is done. For those who pay an insurance stamp the contribution is collected automatically and this is probably a very simple way. Farmers with a valuation of less than £60 whose main income is derived from farming pay their health contribution direct to the health board. Those who are self-employed and earning less than £3,000 pay their contribution to the Revenue Commissioners. Sometimes there is a delay for the last group in that they have to get an auditor's return to send to the Revenue Commissioners and then there can be a delay in getting into benefit. Another problem in relation to the health contribution is that the health contribution year starts on 1 October and the increase in cost in the health contribution generally dates from 1 April. This in effect means that if you pay your health contribution on 1 October you are due a further instalment on 1 April in any year that there is an increase.

In relation to the hardship clause, anywhere there is a means test there will always be the occasional case of hardship. In my health board area the CEO has on occasion used his discretion where there have been genuine cases of hardship. I have never seen it as a problem that anybody was denied the medical service either at hospital level or at general medical service level because he or she was outside the guidelines laid down or outside the £3,000 limit in the case of hospitals. In relation to the means test for hospital service one has to have regard only to the situation where a single person with an income of £3,000 is entitled to benefit while perhaps a married man with a large family and earning just more than £3,000 is excluded. The CEO has discretionary powers in hardship cases. Certainly, the CEO in my area uses this discretion. Those who are not entitled to benefit in respect of hospital services are usually covered by voluntary health insurance so it is unusual to find someone who has no cover whatever.

The Minister has told us that of the 640,000 persons covered by voluntary health insurance, 190,000 qualify for limited eligibility. That is a significant proportion. Another point made was that the emphasis should be on community care rather than on hospitalisation and that the priority should be on extending the general medical service rather than extending the eligibility limit in respect of the cost of hospitalisation. That should be the fundamental aim of any health service because, first, patients are not anxious to go into hospital if there is a possibility that they can be treated at home. Before the general medical practitioner service came into being patients often opted to go to hospital even for minor complaints because the cost involved in being treated there would be less than the cost involved in being treated at home, having regard to doctors' fees, cost of drugs and so on in cases where there were no medical cards. That situation must have been responsible for much unnecessary cost to the health services. In those days the cost of hospitalisation to those earning less than a certain amount was only 50p per day. The present situation is that 70 per cent of the health service cost is in respect of hospitals as against 24 per cent for community care. This is a situation that one would like to see reversed. There is need for much greater development of the community services.
I support fully the Minister's amendment. Having regard to the Minister's statement concerning those whose incomes are more than £3,000, I do not see any need for an immediate change.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Overseas Development Assistance Division.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs in respect of the overseas development assistance division of his Department, (a) the number of executive staff (i) sanctioned and (ii) employed in each year to date; (b) the main areas of responsibility of the division; and (c) if the work of the division has expanded since its establishment; and, if so, in what respects.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: (a) Staff
The Overseas Development Assistance Section was established in 1974. Previously the work of the section was dealt with by the Economic Division.
The number of executive staff (Higher Executive Officer grade and higher) sanctioned and employed in the section from 1974 to 1976 was
2 Counsellors
2 First Secretaries
1 Third Secretary
2 Higher Executive Officers
The staffing of the Section was strengthened in 1977 by the creation of new posts of
1 First Secretary and
1 Higher Executive Officer
In 1978, a subsection of the Economic Division dealing with Community trade relations with developing countries was transferred to the section. This sub-section consists of the following staff
1 First Secretary
2 Third Secretaries
The section is under the responsibility of an Assistant Secretary who also has other sections under his control.
(b) Main Areas of Responsibility

MainHeading.P: (i) In the multilateral area, the main responsibility of the Section is Irish participation in the elaboration of the European Community's development co-operation policies. These policies are pursued either (i) by direct agreements between the Community and developing countries e.g. Convention of Lomé or (ii) in wider international fora such as the UN, UNCTAD, and so forth in the context of the “North-South Dialogue” between industrialised and developing countries.

(ii) Management of the Department's Bilateral Aid Programme, participation in the technical management of the aid programmes of the European Community, administration of the funds voted annually for disaster relief, the publicising of Irish development aid policy, and the mobilisation of Irish resources in response to, and in order to derive national benefit from, the aid programmes of international organisations. This latter responsibility includes the recruitment of Irish personnel for, and the training in this country of persons on behalf of, these organisations
(c) Expansion of Work

As regards the multilateral area the European Community's own programmes of development co-operation have expanded considerably since 1974. Negotiations on the Lomé Convention were concluded in early 1975 and it entered into force in April 1976. The convention which is now due for renegotiation is the most comprehensive agreement concluded in the field of development co-operation between industrialised and developing countries. Also in 1976 the Co-operation Agreements with certain Mediterranean countries were concluded and new programmes of aid for nonassociated developing countries and for co-operation with non-governmental organisations were established. The Community's food aid programmes have been increased and the process of harmonising member states' development policies has been intensified. Over the same period there has been a series of major international conferences dealing with economic co-operation and development in which the European Community has taken an increasingly active part, for example, Special Sessions of the United Nations General Assembly (April 1974 and September 1975), the Fourth United Nations Conference on Trade and Development—UNCTAD (May 1976) and the Conference on International Economic Co-operation (Paris. October 1975—June 1977). A further Special Session of the UN General Assembly to deal specifically with development matters will be held in 1980 and in preparation for this the UN Overview Committee has been established to monitor the entire range of negotiations which are under way in various fora. Community co-ordination in preparation for these multilateral negotiating sessions and meetings is becoming more and more intensive.

The work in the bilateral area has also increased very considerably. This is due in large part to the substantial anual growth of the Bilateral Aid Programme. This programme is planned, administered and executed by the Department and since 1974, when it was established, the amount available to the programme has been increased sixfold. Since 1975 the section has been responsible for participation in the technical management of the aid programmes of the Community which were established under the Lomé Convention. These programmes include the European Development Fund (EDF) Committee, which manages financial and technical assistance grants, and the Article 22 committee which manages loans, granted with interest rate subsidy, by the European Investment Bank (EIB). Likewise, when other Community agreements become operational in the technical assistance area, the section assumes responsibility for participation in their technical management. This is beginning to happen at the moment, for instance, in the case of the agreements between the Community and the Maghreb and Machrek countries.

Speaker.P: Dining/assembly areas, which may be termed all-purpose, are provided in all new secondary schools and in major extensions to secondary schools as part of the normal schedule of accommodation. My Department pay capital grants in respect of these areas in accordance with the rules governing the payment of grants to secondary schools. My Department operate a scheme for the payment of grants towards the cost of furnishing and equipping rooms in secondary schools for the teaching of certain subjects, including physical education. Provision is made for the payment of—
(a) a capital grant for the furnishing and/or equipping of a room not already furnished or equipped or a room which is inadequately furnished or equipped, and
(b) a grant for the renewal or replacement of equipment.

The level of grant is 70 per cent of vouched approved expenditure subject in the case of the capital grant to a maximum of £530. There is no specified fixed upper limit to the amount of a renewal or replacement grant. A school seeking to obtain a grant must comply with the regulations laid down by my Department.
